verses.text: In the twelfth year of Ahaz king of Judah, Hoshea son of Elah became king over Israel in Samaria, and he reigned for nine years.
verses.comment: Hoshea was the last king of Israel. The mention of his reign’s timing anchors the narrative within God’s providential unfolding of history.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, but not as the kings of Israel who were before him.
verses.comment: Hoshea’s evil is contrasted with previous kings’ greater wickedness, underscoring the persistent deviation from God’s covenant.

verses.text: Shalmaneser king of Assyria came up against him, and Hoshea became his servant and paid tribute.
verses.comment: Hoshea’s subjugation to Assyria shows Israel’s loss of autonomy, a consequence of abandoning God’s protection.

verses.text: But the king of Assyria found conspiracy in Hoshea, for he had sent messengers to So king of Egypt and had not paid tribute to the king of Assyria as he had done in previous years. Therefore, the king of Assyria arrested him and imprisoned him.
verses.comment: Hoshea’s attempt to secure foreign alliances reveals the temptation to trust political schemes over faithfulness to God.

verses.text: Then the king of Assyria invaded the whole land. He went up to Samaria and besieged it for three years.
verses.comment: Samaria’s siege corresponds to prophetic warnings about Israel’s destruction due to their covenant infidelity.

verses.text: In the ninth year of Hoshea, the king of Assyria took Samaria and carried Israel away to Assyria. He settled them in Halah, and on the Habor, the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes.
verses.comment: The exile of Israel marks the fulfillment of warnings against idolatry, pointing to the seriousness of attaching oneself to the true faith community.

verses.text: This happened because the sons of Israel had sinned against the LORD their God, who brought them up out of the land of Egypt from under the hand of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and they had feared other gods.
verses.comment: Israel’s idolatry violates the first commandment. Redemption from Egypt prefigures the greater deliverance offered through Christ.

verses.text: They walked in the customs of the nations whom the LORD had driven out before the sons of Israel, and in the practices of the kings of Israel which they had introduced.
verses.comment: Israel’s imitation of pagan customs contrasts with their call to holiness and distinctiveness as God’s people.

verses.text: The sons of Israel secretly did things against the LORD their God that were not right. They built high places in all their towns, from the watchtower to fortified city.
verses.comment: Secret sin and idolatry spread throughout Israel, undermining covenant fidelity. Spiritual integrity requires upright external and internal worship.

verses.text: They set up pillars and Asherim on every high hill and under every green tree.
verses.comment: The proliferation of pagan shrines illustrates Israel’s syncretism and forgetting God’s commands about rightful worship.

verses.text: There they burned incense on all the high places, as the nations had done whom the LORD had carried away before them, and they did evil things to provoke the LORD to anger.
verses.comment: Incense, often a sign of prayer, is corrupt when offered illicitly. Right worship orientates the faithful toward God alone.

verses.text: They served idols about which the LORD had said to them, 'You shall not do this.'
verses.comment: God’s clarity against idolatry emphasizes fidelity in both heart and ritual, anticipating the exclusive devotion later taught by Christ.

verses.text: Yet the LORD warned Israel and Judah by every prophet and every seer, saying, 'Turn from your evil ways and keep My commandments and My statutes according to all the law which I commanded your ancestors, and which I sent to you by My servants the prophets.'
verses.comment: The sending of prophets prefigures the role of Church authority to admonish and preserve the true faith. Repentance is always offered before judgment.

verses.text: But they would not listen, but stiffened their necks like their ancestors, who did not believe in the LORD their God.
verses.comment: Persistent unbelief highlights the need for docility and faith, both qualities emphasized for safeguarding genuine tradition.

verses.text: They rejected His statutes, His covenant which He made with their ancestors, and His warnings He gave them. They followed worthless idols and became worthless themselves, and followed the nations around them, concerning whom the LORD had commanded them not to act like them.
verses.comment: Following false gods deforms character. Covenant fidelity forms the basis of spiritual identity; this points forward to deeper belonging in Christ’s Church.

verses.text: They abandoned all the commandments of the LORD their God, made for themselves molten images, two calves, made an Asherah, and worshiped all the host of heaven, and served Baal.
verses.comment: Israel’s fall included all forms of idolatry; the golden calves recall the original sin of the Exodus generation.

verses.text: They made their sons and daughters pass through fire, practiced divination and sought omens, and sold themselves to do evil in the sight of the LORD, to provoke Him to anger.
verses.comment: Child sacrifice and occult practices are the most serious rejections of divine order, foreshadowing the need for pure worship and sanctification.

verses.text: Therefore the LORD was very angry at Israel and removed them from His sight; no one was left but the tribe of Judah alone.
verses.comment: Judgment falls on Israel; only the southern faithful remnant remains, through whom the promise continues toward the Messiah.

verses.text: Judah also did not keep the commandments of the LORD their God, but followed the customs that Israel had introduced.
verses.comment: Even those set apart can fall. This warns that mere outward inheritance does not guarantee faithfulness; ongoing renewal of worship is necessary.

verses.text: So the LORD rejected all the descendants of Israel, afflicted them, and gave them into the hand of plunderers, until He cast them out of His presence.
verses.comment: God’s justice and purification sometimes require severe mercy. The removal from God’s presence points to the eventual restoration through Christ’s mediation.

verses.text: For He tore Israel away from the house of David, and they made Jeroboam son of Nebat king; and Jeroboam led Israel away from following the LORD and made them commit a great sin.
verses.comment: The division after Solomon’s reign began a trajectory toward apostasy. The single kingdom model hints at Christ’s reunification of all believers.

verses.text: The sons of Israel walked in all the sins that Jeroboam had committed; they did not turn away from them.
verses.comment: Continuing in sin without repentance always leads to separation from divine favor; communal sin can be pervasive.

verses.text: Until the LORD removed Israel from His sight, as He had spoken through all His servants the prophets. So Israel was carried away from their own land to Assyria to this day.
verses.comment: Prophetic warnings are fulfilled. The exile remains the lens through which New Testament restoration (e.g., return from exile in Christ) is understood.

verses.text: The king of Assyria brought people from Babylon, Cuthah, Avva, Hamath, and Sepharvaim, and settled them in the cities of Samaria instead of the sons of Israel. They took possession of Samaria and lived in its cities.
verses.comment: Foreign settling in Samaria lays the foundation for later Samaritan religious syncretism encountered in the Gospels (cf. John 4:9).

verses.text: At the beginning of their stay, they did not fear the LORD; therefore the LORD sent lions among them, which killed some of them.
verses.comment: Divine discipline persists, even for foreigners. This episode prefigures the importance of worshiping in truth, no matter one’s origin.

verses.text: So they spoke to the king of Assyria, saying, 'The nations whom you have removed and settled in the cities of Samaria do not know the way of the god of the land; therefore He has sent lions among them, and behold, they kill them because they do not know the way of the god of the land.'
verses.comment: Recognition of local divinity, though incomplete, shows the link between worship and well-being. Full revelation comes only later, through Christ.

verses.text: Then the king of Assyria commanded, saying, 'Send one of the priests whom you brought from there; let him go and live there and teach them the way of the god of the land.'
verses.comment: Returning priests to teach right worship highlights the importance of priestly teaching and liturgical leadership.

verses.text: So one of the priests whom they had carried off from Samaria came and lived at Bethel, and taught them how they should fear the LORD.
verses.comment: Priestly instruction is regarded as necessary for proper worship—a principle found throughout Christian tradition in the role of teaching authority.

verses.text: However, every nation still made gods of their own and put them in the shrines in the high places that the Samaritans had made; every nation in the cities where they lived.
verses.comment: Idolatry persists even with knowledge about the LORD. Universal tendency toward syncretism calls for vigilance in upholding pure faith.

verses.text: The men of Babylon made Succoth-benoth, the men of Cuth made Nergal, the men of Hamath made Ashima,
verses.comment: The text lists foreign gods introduced by pagan settlers, emphasizing the fragmentation that arises outside of divine revelation.

verses.text: The Avvites made Nibhaz and Tartak; the Sepharvites burned their children in the fire to Adrammelech and Anammelech, the gods of Sepharvaim.
verses.comment: Idolatrous worship included heinous practices, which later scripture condemns utterly (cf. Jer 7:31; Christ exposes all wickedness).

verses.text: They also feared the LORD and appointed from among themselves priests of the high places, who operated for them in the shrines of the high places.
verses.comment: Unauthorized priesthood points to disorder in worship, in contrast to apostolic succession intended for unity and continuity (cf. Acts 1:20–26).

verses.text: They feared the LORD, but they also served their own gods according to the custom of the nations from which they had been carried away.
verses.comment: Dual worship is unacceptable; true religion demands exclusive devotion. Christ later teaches worship in spirit and truth (John 4:24).

verses.text: To this day they continue to act according to their earlier customs. They do not fear the LORD, and they do not follow His statutes or His ordinances, or the law and commandments which the LORD commanded the sons of Jacob, whom He named Israel.
verses.comment: Persistence in error proves the need for ongoing conversion. Jacob/Israel’s name change mirrors the transformation possible through grace.

verses.text: The LORD had made a covenant with them and had commanded them, 'You shall not fear other gods, nor bow down to them, nor serve them, nor sacrifice to them.'
verses.comment: The covenant commands exclusive worship, anticipating Jesus’ insistence on undivided love for God (cf. Matt 6:24).

verses.text: But you shall fear the LORD, who brought you up from the land of Egypt with great power and an outstretched arm. Him you shall fear, to Him you shall bow down, and to Him you shall sacrifice.
verses.comment: Worship is rooted in deliverance and divine might. Sacrifice and bowing prefigure Christian worship’s fulfillment in Christ's sacrifice.

verses.text: And the statutes, ordinances, the law and the commandment which He wrote for you, you shall always observe, and you shall not fear other gods.
verses.comment: Perpetual obedience is demanded; tradition and law serve as ongoing guides, foreshadowing the stability of Christian doctrine.

verses.text: And the covenant that I have made with you, you shall not forget, nor shall you fear other gods.
verses.comment: Memory of covenant sustains identity; New Testament teaching on remembrance correlates (cf. Luke 22:19).

verses.text: But the LORD your God you shall fear; He will deliver you from the hand of all your enemies.
verses.comment: Deliverance is motivated by faithful worship and points to messianic salvation, fulfilled in Christ (cf. Col 1:13–14).

verses.text: However, they did not listen, but continued in their former customs.
verses.comment: Refusal to heed divine instruction reveals the ongoing battle between tradition and innovation. True reform is only possible through grace.

verses.text: So these nations feared the LORD, but also served their carved images; both their children and grandchildren continue, as their ancestors did, to this day.
verses.comment: Mixed worship persists through generations, underscoring the necessity of spiritual formation and the transmission of authentic faith.
